commit_message:
Allow passing node UUID to lookup

After successful inspection we will know node UUID already, so no need
to do a proper lookup. In the future we might get rid of lookup completely
in this case.

Change-Id: Ic00049bf69f9ecc59ac4e389a3e6afe20ba67aba

commit_message:
Delete redundant and add missing tab in information category

The 'Default Quotas' and 'Host Aggregates' tab is
not sub tab in information category. And also the
"Block Storage Services" and "Orchestration Services"
tab are missing in information category. This patch
fix them.

Closes-Bug: #1487933
Change-Id: I0dca7bba19a20a004424cce6d789cec3e9b9b7a3

commit_message:
Fix compatibility with sqlalchemy 0.9.7

Change  I326c00b8252f2630e72bb0c22ca294f79feee2be introduced sqlalchmey
1.0+ only Table attribute foreign_key_constraints. It should be sufficient
to use foreign_keys as only name is needed.

Closes-Bug: #1487351
Change-Id: I38dd8ab620cbe372265eb0568d806cf1c37d5e14

commit_message:
Handle a skipped test without a reason message

This commit fixes a bug in subunit-trace where if a test is skipped
but does not have a reason associated with the skip it would stack
trace. This checks for the existence of a reason before trying to
use it.

Change-Id: I14dd9fbb40a8c232431e5042aa46f7e521e15311
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-testr refs/changes/59/213459/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: reason = test['details'].get('reason', '') if reason: reason = ': ' + reason.as_text() stream.write('{%s} %s ... SKIPPED%s\n' % ( worker, name, reason))

commit_message:
Replace conductor proxying calls with the new VolumeUsage object

This change replace current conductor proxying for db.vol_usage_update()
by instead making use of the brand new VolumeUsage object.

Necessary changes are made to conductor manager to continue work with
the change to use dot notation in compute_utils.usage_volume_info().

Related to blueprint liberty-objects

Change-Id: Icc1caf2e0aa0c88bee044ffce9dcdcee6434de47

commit_message:
QoS: fix get bandwidth limit rules to filter them per policy

add qos_policy_id as filter before calling
QosBandwidthLimitRule.get_objects to get the bw rule(s)
which attached to that policy.

Closes-Bug: #1486053
Change-Id: Ie316cbe48c94f113699b09d9784115a3b0ade32f

'QosBandwidthLimitRule.' 'get_objects') as get_object_mock: self.qos_plugin.get_policy_bandwidth_limit_rules( self.ctxt, self.policy.id) get_object_mock.assert_called_once_with( self.ctxt, qos_policy_id=self.policy.id)

commit_message:
Fix plugin loading tests

The plugin loading tests weren't being run because there was no
__init__.py in the loading folder. Add the file and fix the test
breakages that we have otherwise missed.

Change-Id: If5aae690774c47794b5ba3af91878d9fcfacacb6

commit_message:
Migrate to new YAQL 1.0.0

All required changes were made: now global object is used,
arguments of registered functions were updated accordingly.

Also custom pickle objects were introduced to perform correct
serializations to keep data between requests.

Partially implements blueprint: migrate-to-yaql-vnext

commit_message:
test/(functional/probe):Replace python print operator with print function (pep H233, py33)

'print' function is compatible with 2.x and 3.x python versions
Link : https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105/

Python 2.6 has a __future__ import that removes print as language syntax,
letting you use the functional form instead

Change-Id: I416c6ac21ccbfb91ec328ffb1ed21e492ef52d58

commit_message:
Enable password support for vnc session

Enable password support for vnc session. This is to avoid
allowing an attacker to connect to the remote host as no
authentication is required to access this service. The
default vnc password is uuid of the instance, and this feature
can be enabled by setting the enable_vnc_password in nova.conf

Change-Id: I5a875d9921edff6c85ccb5a27c8a28e6bf3432d5
Closes-Bug: 1450294

commit_message:
Add Quota Enforcement API

This commit adds the quota enforcement API.  When emplemented, enforce()
will return without exception if a new resource can be created without
exceeding a quota limit.  enforce() will raise an exception if the
creation needs to be blocked due to the effective quota.  A detailed
error message is created for both the log and the response body of
the create request.

Change-Id: Iaf2a3a3e5960e84c3fe7d9d2becf1cc32b788833
Partially-implements: blueprint quota-support-on-barbican-resources

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-21 14:06:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer-powervm/commit/f74eef63129a378392cad5ca570772e94e4b9389', 'message': "Account for live migrated VMs

In PowerVM, when a VM is migrated, the 'metrics come with it'.  That
means that the metrics are cumulative and you can be assured that when
it is on a new host, its metrics are still valid.

This presents some complications.  The metrics are pulled from the host.
To determine rates, we ask the host for the previous sample and the
current.  Previously we had assumed that if the previous sample was
None, it must be a new VM so all the traffic from the current is 'new'.

With live migration taken into account, we can not do that.  There may
be months of CPU, Network and Storage data in that VMs metrics.  This
really skews the metrics in undesirable ways.

This change set will skip instances (for a given inspection cycle) that
are in the current sample but not the previous.  This does lose a sample
cycle, but ensures that we maintain accurracy (which is more important).

commit_message:
Account for live migrated VMs

In PowerVM, when a VM is migrated, the 'metrics come with it'.  That
means that the metrics are cumulative and you can be assured that when
it is on a new host, its metrics are still valid.

This presents some complications.  The metrics are pulled from the host.
To determine rates, we ask the host for the previous sample and the
current.  Previously we had assumed that if the previous sample was
None, it must be a new VM so all the traffic from the current is 'new'.

With live migration taken into account, we can not do that.  There may
be months of CPU, Network and Storage data in that VMs metrics.  This
really skews the metrics in undesirable ways.

This change set will skip instances (for a given inspection cycle) that
are in the current sample but not the previous.  This does lose a sample
cycle, but ensures that we maintain accurracy (which is more important).

Change-Id: Iba7f1287b3433acd8517947e01cbfa14fe93413c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer-powervm refs/changes/49/215649/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ceilometer.i18n import _LW # If there is no previous sample, that is either a new VM or is # a live migrated system. A live migrated system will pull all # of its metrics with it. The issue with this is it could have # CPU cycles for months of run time. So we can't really determine # the CPU utilization within the last X seconds...because to THIS # host its new (only in the cur_metric). So we error out, the # inspector will use a debug message in the log. LOG.warn(_LW("Unable to derive CPU Utilization for VM %s. It is " "either a new VM or was recently migrated. It will " "be collected in the next inspection cycle."), instance.name) message = (_("Unable to derive CPU Utilization for VM %s.") % instance.name) raise virt_inspector.InstanceNotFoundException(message) # Gather the previous metrics prev_util_cap = prev_metric.processor.util_cap_proc_cycles prev_util_uncap = prev_metric.processor.util_uncap_proc_cycles prev_idle = prev_metric.processor.idle_proc_cycles prev_donated = prev_metric.processor.donated_proc_cycles prev_entitled = prev_metric.processor.entitled_proc_cycles if (cur_metric.network is None or prev_metric is None or prev_metric.network is None): date_delta_num = float((cur_date - prev_date).seconds) # Note that here, the previous may be none. That simply indicates # that the adapter was dynamically added to the VM before the # previous collection. Not the migration scenario above. # In this case, we can default the base to 0. # The previous adapter may be None. This simply indicates that the # adapter was added between the previous sample and this one. It # does not indicate a live migrate scenario like noted above, as # the VM itself hasn't moved. prev_adpt = find_prev(cur_adpt) prev_ops = ((prev_adpt.num_reads + prev_adpt.num_writes) if prev_adpt else 0)
deleted_lines: # If there is no previous sample, we blanket these to zero. All # the cycles that were used in the current sample are 'fully' # utilized. prev_util_cap = 0 prev_util_uncap = 0 prev_idle = 0 prev_donated = 0 prev_entitled = 0 else: prev_util_cap = prev_metric.processor.util_cap_proc_cycles prev_util_uncap = prev_metric.processor.util_uncap_proc_cycles prev_idle = prev_metric.processor.idle_proc_cycles prev_donated = prev_metric.processor.donated_proc_cycles prev_entitled = prev_metric.processor.entitled_proc_cycles if cur_metric.network is None: # However, if there is no previous sample, then we have to estimate. # Therefore, we estimate 15 seconds - half of the standard 30 seconds. date_delta = ((cur_date - prev_date) if prev_date is not None else datetime.timedelta(seconds=15)) date_delta_num = float(date_delta.seconds) prev_adpt = find_prev(cur_adpt) if prev_adpt is None: # Perhaps this is a new adapter, was recently LPM'd, etc... # Don't assume 0, just skip until the next pull. continue prev_ops = prev_adpt.num_reads + prev_adpt.num_writes

commit_message:
Spec for deployer plugins

Deployer plugins allow for flexibility and extensibility
in application target architectures supported by Solum

Change-Id: I0ceb3b71dcdf415e165e5b48b8eebf2ec6817593
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum-specs refs/changes/54/202254/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================ Deployer Plugins ================ Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/solum/+spec/deployer_plugins Currently, any customization or user-selectable variety in application deployment architecture is exclusively governed by available Heat templates that the single deployer has access to. While sufficient for a few simple architectural flavors sharing the same parameter requirements and update workflows, more numerous and complex options make this single deployer design untenable. Problem description =================== The current deployer design makes implementing many types of architectural flavor options difficult if not impossible. Relying solely on different templates is insufficient since customization is limited by having to either restrict the needs of these architectures to a strictly limited set of parameters or requiring every template to include every possible parameter of every other template. Additionally, this mechanism doesn't allow for various different update strategies. For example, an HA architectural flavor may require multiple calls to stack update and modifications to the template that simply cannot be accounted for in a "one-size-fits-all" deployer design. Finally, the current design requires operators to patch the deployer should they wish to rely on different deployment mechanisms and/or workflows. Proposed change =============== The proposed change would use Stevadore plugins to allow the deployer to be easily extended to support various different architectural flavors. These plugins would also expose any additional parameters that are relevent and/or allowed for the particular architectural flavor it implements. Functionality such as generating pre-authenticated urls and general preable would still be handled by the current deployer class. However, in this proposed design, the deployer would pass parameters and other user selections on to the desired plugin which would then handle the actual deployment (template selection, manipulation, and interaction with Heat or other provisioning strategies). The plugin will also be responsible for monitoring provisioning status and reporting same to the deployer. Each plugin would optionally define properties similar to the way Heat resource plugins do. These allow the plugin author to define the user-configurable options available for that architectural flavor. Property definition will be similar to that found in Heat resource plugins. When an application is created, the user will be able to pass property values which are then validated and used in provisioning by the chosen plugin. Alternatives ------------ As mentioned in the Problem Description, various templates and ever-branching logic in the deployer code could be relied on for a time, but this is untenable in the long term. Data model impact ----------------- The ``app`` table will need to be modified to include a ``flavor`` column to identify the plugin used to deploy the application. Since the deployer plugin is now responsible for provisioning, the ``stack_id`` column can be replaced by a generic column called ``deployer_info``. This column can contain arbitrary data that the specific plugin needs (stack ids, persistent property values, etc). REST API impact --------------- The api would be extended to include the following calls: *GET /flavors* Return a list of supported architectural flavors: - Response codes: 200 - Returns a list of flavors and their short descriptions *GET /flavors/<flavor>* Return details of the specified flavor: - Response codes: 200 - Returns details of a flavor similar to the response from ``heat resource-type-show`` Additionally, application creation and update would be extended to accept parameters. These parameters and their values will be validated by the plugin implementing the specified flavor. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- Python-solum client will need to add the following corresponding methods: * ``solum flavor list`` Return a list of supported architectural flavors * ``solum flavor show`` Return details of the specified flavor Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will need to be aware of plugin packaging and deployment should they wish to use this mechanism for Developer impact ---------------- This is a new method of adding and maintaining deployer code. Developers will need to be aware of and familiar with Stevadore plugins and how they are defined, registered, and loaded. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: randallburt Work Items ---------- * include Stevedore and create deployer plugin base class * refactor current deployer to load plugins for flavors * refactor existing "basic" flavor to be a plugin * refactor tests and add coverage for manager and basic plugin * add flavor listing and detail to the api * add functional tests (Tempest) for flavor listing and detail * update wadl and python-solumclient docs * add flavor listing and detail to the cli Dependencies ============ * Stevedore <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/stevedore/> will be an additional dependency in ``requirements.txt``. Testing ======= Tempest tests for the new api endpoints will be added to cover basic functionality. Application deployment and other functions should not impact current tests for them; in fact, current tests are required to pass as is to prove no regressions Documentation Impact ==================== The new api endpoints will need to be added to the wadl. Documentation for python-solumclient will need to be updated with the new operations. References ========== None.

commit_message:
PowerVM Storage Inspector

This change set provides base support for the PowerVM compute inspector
to collect the storage devices.

Since PowerVM monitors storage metrics on the 'buses' (rather than a per
device) the metrics are reported based on the bus.  This may be a
virtual SCSI bus or a virtual Fibre Channel bus.

Change-Id: I704c7e79e825b7d5f0f8924c28d502ccbfb9330d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer-powervm refs/changes/26/215326/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def inspect_disks(self, instance): """Inspect the disk statistics for an instance. :param instance: the target instance :return: for each disk, the number of bytes & operations read and written, and the error count """ # Get the current and previous sample. Delta is performed between # these two. uuid = self._puuid(instance) cur_date, cur_metric = self.vm_metrics.get_latest_metric(uuid) # If the cur_metric is none, then the instance can not be found in the # sample and an error should be raised. if cur_metric is None: raise virt_inspector.InstanceNotFoundException( _('VM %s not found in PowerVM Metrics Sample') % instance.name) # If there isn't network information, this is because the Virtual # I/O Metrics were turned off. Have to pass through this method. if cur_metric.storage is None: return # Bundle together the SCSI and virtual FC adapters adpts = cur_metric.storage.virt_adpts + cur_metric.storage.vfc_adpts # Loop through all the storage adapters for adpt in adpts: # PowerVM only shows the connection (SCSI or FC). Name after # the connection name disk = virt_inspector.Disk(device=adpt.name) stats = virt_inspector.DiskStats( read_requests=adpt.num_reads, read_bytes=adpt.read_bytes, write_requests=adpt.num_writes, write_bytes=adpt.write_bytes, errors=0) yield (disk, stats)

subject: Moving the RefStack project from openstack-infra to Big Tent.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-17 23:11:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/a8ee7b8b3f23b39a1969a54e9be7747a4abc5f8b', 'message': 'Moving the RefStack project from openstack-infra to Big Tent.

RefStack is a test result collection and reporting service to
support the DefCore testing process.  RefStack was relocated from
stackforge to openstack-infra [1].  However, there are increasing
feedback and general consensus of the Foundation staff is that
RefStack should be a Big Tent project.
[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/205609/

Change-Id: I2a9f029acc6908deb5486567eadb311b43dffbdb
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-18 07:10:01.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/3de9b87b5e169e2de9f0fa2fcc68ad4470259970', 'message': 'Moving the RefStack project from openstack-infra to Big Tent.

RefStack is a test result collection and reporting service to
support the DefCore testing process. It consumes the output of
DefCore mostly in the form of a Board-approved JSON document,
which it uses to determine whether a cloud has passed all the
tests required by the DefCore Guideline in question.

RefStack has been approved to move from stackforge to
openstack-infra [1]. However, there are increasing feedback
and general consensus of the Foundation staff is that RefStack
should be a Big Tent project.

RefStack has elected PTL and core members.  The core members
approve all code changes.  RefStack code is submitted and
reviewed using the OpenStack infrastructure [2].

RefStack has been running weekly meetings from the start of the
project. Meetings are held on Monday at 19:00 UTC and are open
to anyone that wants to attend. Our Weekly meeting agenda is
published at the meeting wiki [3].

The #refstack IRC channel on freenode is logged and the channel is
notified of such logging [4].

A RefStack server (refstack.openstack.org) will be hosted by
OpenStack Infra [5][6].

commit_message:
Moving the RefStack project from openstack-infra to Big Tent.

RefStack is a test result collection and reporting service to
support the DefCore testing process. It consumes the output of
DefCore mostly in the form of a Board-approved JSON document,
which it uses to determine whether a cloud has passed all the
tests required by the DefCore Guideline in question.

RefStack has been approved to move from stackforge to
openstack-infra [1]. However, there are increasing feedback
and general consensus of the Foundation staff is that RefStack
should be a Big Tent project.

RefStack has elected PTL and core members.  The core members
approve all code changes.  RefStack code is submitted and
reviewed using the OpenStack infrastructure [2].

RefStack has been running weekly meetings from the start of the
project. Meetings are held on Monday at 19:00 UTC and are open
to anyone that wants to attend. Our Weekly meeting agenda is
published at the meeting wiki [3].

The #refstack IRC channel on freenode is logged and the channel is
notified of such logging [4].

A RefStack server (refstack.openstack.org) will be hosted by
OpenStack Infra [5][6].

[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/205609/
[2]https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:stackforge/refstack,n,z
[3]https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Refstack
[4]http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23refstack/
[5]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/188207/
[6[https://review.openstack.org/#/c/198869/

Change-Id: I2a9f029acc6908deb5486567eadb311b43dffbdb

commit_message:
RPCify rule_model

Previously the rule_model manipulated the methods of the
policy engine directly and maintained consistency between
the database and policy engine.  Once the API and policy
engine are running in separate processes, that will no
longer work.

This change introduces the RPC abstraction for the rule_model.
It also moves the maintanence of the policy engine and
database into the policy engine itself, effectively
creating a persistance later for the policy engine.

Also moved a few functions around in the policy engine
to make the layering clearer.

Partially-implements: blueprint dist-api-rpcify-rule
Change-Id: I2be8ef35dd9819036a24e617b3ad1aa268aa2782

subject: Include HTTP error codes in error_codes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-17 22:44:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/4addfebf43b9e518b5a94adbfbdeb3be4c85421b', 'message': 'Include HTTP error codes in error_codes

Previously, error_codes.py was used only at the API layer.  And
HTTP error codes were computed ad-hoc using a combination of
error_codes.py and exception types raised by policy engines and
datasources.

This exception architecture is especially troublesome now that
API models are communicating with policy engines/datasources
via RPC because more of the logic for errors is being pushed
into the policy-engine and datasources.  Thus when exceptions
are raised, they should really contain enough semantics for
the API layer to convert to HTTP error codes.

This change adds HTTP error codes to error_codes and adds
a constructor to the DataModelException that copies the
error_codes from a given exception.  In subsequent changes,
the policy-engine/datasources will raise exceptions with
the appropriate error_codes and the API will transform
them into DataModelExceptions with appropriate HTTP codes.

commit_message:
Include HTTP error codes in error_codes

Previously, error_codes.py was used only at the API layer.  And
HTTP error codes were computed ad-hoc using a combination of
error_codes.py and exception types raised by policy engines and
datasources.

This exception architecture is especially troublesome now that
API models are communicating with policy engines/datasources
via RPC because more of the logic for errors is being pushed
into the policy-engine and datasources.  Thus when exceptions
are raised, they should really contain enough semantics for
the API layer to convert to HTTP error codes.

This change adds HTTP error codes to error_codes and adds
a constructor to the DataModelException that copies the
error_codes from a given exception.  In subsequent changes,
the policy-engine/datasources will raise exceptions with
the appropriate error_codes and the API will transform
them into DataModelExceptions with appropriate HTTP codes.

Partially-implements: blueprint dist-api-rpcify-row
Change-Id: Ic122a3ecd89ae3d9ccafce17d284a921b9b64f32
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/21/213921/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Prepare Policy Model API for RPC

Previously the policy model API used Python pointers to the
policy engine for its implementation.  This won't work when
the API model is running in a different process than the
policy engine.  Also, the API model was responsible for
keeping the in-memory policy engine in sync with the database;
this is unnatural once the policy engine is running in
its own process and using its own database.

This change rewrites the policy model so that it uses
a fake RPC method instead of a direct Python reference to the
policy engine.  It also moves the database synchronization to
the policy engine.

Partially-implements: blueprint dist-api-rpcify-policy
Change-Id: I87116cc43bd280788bb810db6d668f0ca7f4b07a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/91/210691/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import uuidutilsfrom congress.db import db_policy_rules def __init__(self, database=None): # database self.database = database def create_persistent_policy(self, name, id_=None, abbr=None, kind=None, desc=None): # validation try: self.parse("%s() :- true()" % name) except exception.PolicyException: (num, desc) = error_codes.get('policy_name_must_be_id') raise webservice.DataModelException( num, desc + ": " + str(name)) # create policy in policy engine if id_ is None: id_ = str(uuidutils.generate_uuid()) try: policy_obj = self.create_policy( name=name, abbr=abbr, kind=kind) policy_obj.set_id(id_) except exception.PolicyException as e: (num, desc) = error_codes.get('failed_to_create_policy') raise webservice.DataModelException( num, desc + ": " + str(e)) # save policy to database if desc is None: desc = '' obj = {'id': id_, 'name': name, 'owner_id': 'user', 'description': desc, 'abbreviation': policy_obj.abbr, 'kind': policy_obj.kind} # TODO(thinrichs): add rollback of policy engine if this fails db_policy_rules.add_policy(obj['id'], obj['name'], obj['abbreviation'], obj['description'], obj['owner_id'], obj['kind']) return obj def delete_persistent_policy(self, name_or_id): # check that policy exists db_object = self.db_policy_rules.get_policy(name_or_id) if db_object is None: raise KeyError("Cannot delete policy with ID '%s': " "ID '%s' does not exist", name_or_id, name_or_id) if db_object['name'] in ['classification', 'action']: raise KeyError("Cannot delete system-maintained policy %s", db_object['name']) # delete policy from memory and from database self.delete_policy(self, name_or_id) db_policy_rules.delete_policy(name_or_id) def find_policy_name(self, name_or_id): """Given name or ID, return the name of the policy or KeyError.""" if name_or_id in self.theory: return name_or_id for th in self.theory.values(): if th.id == name_or_id: return th.name raise KeyError("Policy %s could not be found" % name_or_id) def delete_policy(self, name_or_id, disallow_dangling_refs=False): LOG.debug("Deleting policy named %s", name_or_id) name = self.find_policy_name(name_or_id) def policies(self): return self.theory result = compile.formulas_to_string(result) if trace: strresult = " ".join(str(x) for x in result[0]) return (result, result[1]) else: return result

commit_message:
Code re-org for distributed architecture

For distributed architecture, certain methods will be moved from
managers/datasource.py to api/datasource_model.py. To facilitate
that change it is necessary to remove the synchronizer code from
api/datasource_model.py

Partially Implelements: blueprint dist-refactor-datasource-manager
Change-Id: I4bc04dc969905fe1d6d36395ad4db0ba90235fd7

subject: No using d6cage to initialize APIRouter()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-12 22:03:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/01a3401178e57591f1d15489b9f24016a7b51202', 'message': "Remove d6cage dependency and direct accesses to theory

API process uses d6cage instance to initialize itself. In Congress
distributed process model, d6cage will be removed. To reduces
dependencies of API class for d6cage instances, this patch makes
the API process use a dict to have references to API instances.

Additionally, this patch changes direct variable accesses to
engine's theories with method accesses as the API process and
datasource processes can't access to engine's variables in the
distributed architecture.

Change-Id: Ia1edff920e7db9c4e97f5d562bcb8fb0da50abf7
Implements: blueprint dist-remove-d6cage-from-api
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-12 22:49:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/ad0702a7f79ea55109eb3492b4f21503f83f8384', 'message': "Remove d6cage dependency and direct accesses to theory

API process uses d6cage instance to initialize itself. In Congress
distributed process model, d6cage will be removed. To reduces
dependencies of API class for d6cage instances, this patch makes
the API process use a dict to have references to API instances.

Additionally, this patch changes direct variable accesses to
engine's theories with method accesses as the API process and
datasource processes can't access to engine's variables in the
distributed architecture.

Change-Id: Ia1edff920e7db9c4e97f5d562bcb8fb0da50abf7

commit_message:
No using d6cage to initialize APIRouter()

APIRouter for an API process uses d6cage to initialize itself now.
This patch gets rid of d6cage access from APIRouter.

Partialy-Implements: blueprint dist-remove-d6cage-from-api
Change-Id: Ia1edff920e7db9c4e97f5d562bcb8fb0da50abf7

Add constraints details to project testing interface

Implements Blueprint: Requirements-Management

Change-Id: I3ce356c431e808578f222862e29fa80aa6a5b174
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/99/215399/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Projects may optionally also support: - Constrained unit tests for python2.7 - Constrained unit tests for python3.4 Projects desiring to support constrained unit tests must support: - tox -epy27-constraints - tox -epy34-constraints those may be listed in requirements.txt or test-requirements.txt using environment makers.Constraints =========== The requirements project maintains a set of constraints with packages pinned to specific package versions that are known to be working. The goal is to ease the diagnosis of breakage caused by projects upstream to OpenStack and to provide a set of packages known to work together. Running constraints enabled jobs in addition to the main tests is optional and left up to individual projects to decide.
deleted_lines: those may optionally be listed in requirements-py3.txt or requirements-pypy.txt.

commit_message:
Add logging.conf to gitignore

Sometimes user wants to specify it's own logging config.
But now it should be excluded from commit all the time.

Change-Id: I323375c7b8e49658fd96a001bd6b8a3dfd675031

added_lines: sb.append("Time_slice(time_stamp, " + period); sb.append(") AS time_interval"); sb.append("group by Time_slice(time_stamp, " + period); sb.append(") order by time_interval");
deleted_lines: sb.append("MIN(time_stamp) as time_interval "); sb.append("FROM (Select FLOOR((EXTRACT('epoch' from time_stamp) - "); sb.append(createOffsetStr(defDimIdSet, period, startTime, endTime, offset)); sb.append(" AS time_slice, time_stamp, value "); sb.append(createWhereClause(startTime, endTime, offset)); sb.append(") as TimeSlices group by time_slice order by time_slice"); private String createOffsetStr( Set<byte[]> defDimIdSet, int period, DateTime startTime, DateTime endTime, String offset) { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); sb.append("(select mod((select extract('epoch' from time_stamp) from MonMetrics.Measurements "); String inClause = createInClause(defDimIdSet); sb.append("WHERE to_hex(definition_dimensions_id) " + inClause); sb.append(createWhereClause(startTime, endTime, offset)); sb.append("order by time_stamp limit 1"); sb.append("),"); sb.append(period + ")))/" + period + ")"); return sb.toString(); } private String createWhereClause( DateTime startTime, DateTime endTime, String offset) { String s = ""; if (startTime != null && endTime != null) { s = "AND time_stamp >= :start_time AND time_stamp <= :end_time "; } else if (startTime != null) { s = "AND time_stamp >= :start_time "; } if (offset != null && !offset.isEmpty()) { s += " and time_stamp > :offset "; } return s; }

commit_message:
Moving translation to HTML for launch-instance keypair step

Translation should be done in html templates instead of javascript.

This change addresses the launch-instance keypair step.

Change-Id: I59542fb6a38e9327219a98e805c93233a7106db0
Partial-Bug: #1487582

Add container sync probe test to SAIO default set

SAIO Configuration and documentation changes enabling to run the
container sync probe test by default

commit_message:
Modify the manage command prompt information

-- Change host@driver[#pool] to host@driver#pool,
   because pool is a required parameter.
-- Change <share_type> to <share-type>, Make this
   consistent with 'manila create' command prompt
   information.
-- Add example for export_path.

Closes-Bug: #1481611
Change-Id: I4991389a3b0666eea5fb801071bb9b9557519e80

subject: Make Resource.find more generically applicable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-19 22:43:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/04efeb83a450e76bf84db8026629786efe50ce48', 'message': "Make Resource.find more generically applicable

The previous Resource.find was using query parameters of
id= and name= after directly attempting Resource.get_by_id.
In a few cases, this actually works, such as on Server.find
where it's able to accept the name= query parameter and
properly return a match. However, most other resources don't
work with those query parameters, so unless the find was done
by ID, there was very little chance of finding a match.

This change keeps mostly the same structure but does so without
using query parameters. It keeps the original Resource.get_by_id
to potentially find an immediate match, but if it needs to look
further it does so by making one request for all data and then
possibly two loops over the data to match the requested string
to an id or name attribute.

This refactoring ends up fixing several outstanding bugs for
certain resources' find methods not working. It additionally
fixes a bug where searches by name would raise DuplicateResource
both when a single match existed, duplicate matches existed,
and also when no match existed. This was due to the baked in
query parameter logic and assumption that it was working causing
us to handle those responses differently than what they were
really signifying.

Change-Id: I4ae0599334b73b14a36a6f63bc8b26343abb1466

commit_message:
Make Resource.find more generically applicable

The previous Resource.find was using query parameters of
id= and name= after directly attempting Resource.get_by_id.
In a few cases, this actually works, such as on Server.find
where it's able to accept the name= query parameter and
properly return a match. However, most other resources don't
work with those query parameters, so unless the find was done
by ID, there was very little chance of finding a match.

This change keeps mostly the same structure but does so without
using query parameters. It keeps the original Resource.get_by_id
to potentially find an immediate match, but if it needs to look
further it does so by making one request for all data and then
looks at both the name and id attributes in a loop to find a matching
resource.

This refactoring ends up fixing several outstanding bugs for
certain resources' find methods not working. It additionally
fixes a bug where searches by name would raise DuplicateResource
both when a single match existed, duplicate matches existed,
and also when no match existed. This was due to the baked in
query parameter logic and assumption that it was working causing
us to handle those responses differently than what they were
really signifying.

Change-Id: I4ae0599334b73b14a36a6f63bc8b26343abb1466
Closes-Bug: 1466174
Closes-Bug: 1384230
Closes-Bug: 1456317
Closes-Bug: 1455768
Closes-Bug: 1486705

commit_message:
API v1.1 Claims endpoints

This change adds the endpoints for claims to the
persistent transport API.

commit_message:
Fix WS deauthenticate

Properly handle timezones in the WebSocket deauthenticate call. It also
updates the example to handle auth, and pass the proper action in
results.

Change-Id: I7b3b38764e6d275f9c2b29c8a09a6a947bf9bebf

commit_message:
Remove the ironic.config.sample file

This file is not gated and therefore it gets out of date.  Replacing it
with a README that explains how to generate it

This is basically a cross-port of Nova's change:
  I2a72a005208a2c86d69ac461d72e54c53bd395cf

Change-Id: If1489d3296c3170a2d9856e54cd98b92f874d1b7

commit_message:
Add plugin docs section on configuration options

This commit adds a subsubsection to the plugin interface docs to
elaborate a bit on how to deal with configuration options. Previously,
how to use them in a plugin was implied, but nothing was explicitly
stated. This corrects that to make it clear on how to deal with
configuration.

Change-Id: Id3afc9657c5419cfba61acb3c84ccfea104d1b20
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/66/216266/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Dealing with configuration options ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Historically Tempest didn't provide external guarantees on its configuration options. However, with the introduction of the plugin interface this is no longer the case. An external plugin can rely on using any configuration option coming from Tempest, there will be at least a full deprecation cycle for any option before it's removed. However, the just the options provided by Tempest may not be sufficient for the plugin. If you need to add any plugin specific configuration options you should use the ``register_opts`` and ``get_opt_lists`` methods to pass them to Tempest when the plugin is loaded.

commit_message:
Return complete resp from sec grp default rule client

Currently compute security_group_default_rules_client returns Response by
removing top key from Response.
For example-
 return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['security_group_default_rule'])

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current
way of return value. Resource pagination links are present in parallel
(not inside) to top key of Response.

This patch makes compute security_group_default_rules_client to return
complete Response body.

Change-Id: Ie39cb8a0d710c1412836f93ce6b3df60faad9f76
Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib

commit_message:
file: fix potential race condition in storing measure

We currently do open/mkdir/open in the case where the first open fails.
Though it might be rare, but it's possible that between mkdir and open a
rmdir occurs, and therefore the second open will fail again too.

So let's replace that by a infinite loop instead.

Change-Id: Iec65528415c5b8e832c173dda47815d4e2c943bb

In this case, good for us, let's do # nothing then! (see bug #1475684) if e.errno != errno.EEXIST: raise

commit_message:
Remove v3 api from paste configuration

v3 was dropped in favor of v2.1, we should clean up this externalized
reference which also lets us drop the v3 specific noauth middleware
(not used anywhere else)

Co-Authored-By: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>
Closes-Bug: #1428136
Change-Id: I74cedf9350cd9ee3c5f622e038f041fe3f7838cd

commit_message:
Flavor created only when flavorid is an integer

Initially, when the "id" was set to non-integer
or non-UUID, the flavor was also created successfully.

Now, with this patch we are able to create a flavor
with "id" only.

Change-Id: I937c7fb98ec13b3a5014cf8ef3a0c5948f237efe
Closes-Bug: #1426806

commit_message:
default_schedule_zone should be a list of AZ(s)

Operator may have more than one AZ that they would like their
users to boot to by default. This also helps in the case as
described in the bug report where an operator may want to
specify all their AZ(s) *except* for one special AZ. So this
gives more power to the operators.

Since not all az's listed in default_schedule_zones list may be
available at the specific time, we should pick at random from
a subset of those that are actually available.

Note that we use a MultiStrOpt which will help keep the compatability
with the older config files.

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: #1474467
Change-Id: I5f69319b0a3c36043a04d4301dc0fac36b7d4170

commit_message:
Remove the ips method from server.py

It is not a good idea to have the parent dependent on the
child.

Change-Id: I856665249252ede522a8e15639d122de381ee5c7

commit_message:
Get rid of example command line options

Everett mentioned cleaning up the example code and I'd like to
start this by removing the command line options.  There is a lot
of complexity there I'd sooner not maintain.  I'm pretty sure
some of it is broken.  It is also different than other CLIs.
Use OCC.

Change-Id: If759e02ede4baee5277c1a8a4bc9f2dca13f6c82

subject: storage: remove create_metric()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-17 18:00:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/89cf53ce47b8b8773fa28ff644bf569781649a85', 'message': "storage: remove create_metric()

This changes the storage driver API so that there's no need to create
metric before adding metrics. We let the indexer be responsible for the
status of a metric to be existing or non existing, and we allow the
storage driver to create metric on the fly.

Pros:

1. Speeds up the metric creation process as we do not need to reach the
   storage to create a container + empty archives
2. Avoid us for a COMMIT/ROLLBACK step we would have to handle in the
   metric creation process, in the case where creating a metric either
   storage or indexer would fail – we would have to rollback the
   creation that did not fail.

Cons:

1. We now acknowledge that it's more difficult to have an autonomous
   storage driver working without an indexer. While this was no obvious
   before Gnocchi 1.0.0, it's getting pretty clear now that we don't
   want to bypass the indexer as it's anyway responsible for things such
   as RBAC. And we can anyway cache him.

Change-Id: I81ff5ca5540a8a02d378c289bed611a1329f9325
Related-Bugs: #1483634
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-17 20:47:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/b332e5080eb8cba0549732a826509e6e19b3b062', 'message': "storage: remove create_metric()

This changes the storage driver API so that there's no need to create
metric before adding metrics. We let the indexer be responsible for the
status of a metric to be existing or non existing, and we allow the
storage driver to create metric on the fly.

Pros:

1. Speeds up the metric creation process as we do not need to reach the
   storage to create a container + empty archives
2. Avoid us for a COMMIT/ROLLBACK step we would have to handle in the
   metric creation process, in the case where creating a metric either
   storage or indexer would fail – we would have to rollback the
   creation that did not fail.

Cons:

1. We now acknowledge that it's more difficult to have an autonomous
   storage driver working without an indexer. While this was no obvious
   before Gnocchi 1.0.0, it's getting pretty clear now that we don't
   want to bypass the indexer as it's anyway responsible for things such
   as RBAC. And we can anyway cache him.

This will help fixing bug #1483634 since we'll be able to create metric
only in the indexer, doing that in only one single transaction.

Change-Id: I81ff5ca5540a8a02d378c289bed611a1329f9325
Related-Bug: #1483634
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-18 10:38:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/4ead5e0f668a24f022dbac4b8e8efd0a7646caa3', 'message': "storage: remove create_metric()

This changes the storage driver API so that there's no need to create
metric before adding metrics. We let the indexer be responsible for the
status of a metric to be existing or non existing, and we allow the
storage driver to create metric on the fly.

Pros:

1. Speeds up the metric creation process as we do not need to reach the
   storage to create a container + empty archives
2. Avoid us for a COMMIT/ROLLBACK step we would have to handle in the
   metric creation process, in the case where creating a metric either
   storage or indexer would fail – we would have to rollback the
   creation that did not fail.

Cons:

1. We now acknowledge that it's more difficult to have an autonomous
   storage driver working without an indexer. While this was no obvious
   before Gnocchi 1.0.0, it's getting pretty clear now that we don't
   want to bypass the indexer as it's anyway responsible for things such
   as RBAC. And we can anyway cache him.

This will help fixing bug #1483634 since we'll be able to create metric
only in the indexer, doing that in only one single transaction.

This change also handles correctly deletion of unprocessed measures for
metrics that has been deleted.

Change-Id: I81ff5ca5540a8a02d378c289bed611a1329f9325
Related-Bug: #1483634
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-08-20 16:53:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/fbe6a8ebf3901935c4e5506f1a4aefe334712990', 'message': "storage: remove create_metric()

This changes the storage driver API so that there's no need to create
metric before adding metrics. We let the indexer be responsible for the
status of a metric to be existing or non existing, and we allow the
storage driver to create metric on the fly.

Pros:

1. Speeds up the metric creation process as we do not need to reach the
   storage to create a container + empty archives
2. Avoid us for a COMMIT/ROLLBACK step we would have to handle in the
   metric creation process, in the case where creating a metric either
   storage or indexer would fail – we would have to rollback the
   creation that did not fail.

Cons:

1. We now acknowledge that it's more difficult to have an autonomous
   storage driver working without an indexer. While this was no obvious
   before Gnocchi 1.0.0, it's getting pretty clear now that we don't
   want to bypass the indexer as it's anyway responsible for things such
   as RBAC. And we can anyway cache him.

This will help fixing bug #1483634 since we'll be able to create metric
only in the indexer, doing that in only one single transaction.

This change also handles correctly deletion of unprocessed measures for
metrics that has been deleted.

Change-Id: I81ff5ca5540a8a02d378c289bed611a1329f9325

   as RBAC. And we can anyway cache him.

only in the indexer, doing that in only one single transaction.

commit_message:
storage: remove create_metric()

This changes the storage driver API so that there's no need to create
metric before adding metrics. We let the indexer be responsible for the
status of a metric to be existing or non existing, and we allow the
storage driver to create metric on the fly.

Pros:

1. Speeds up the metric creation process as we do not need to reach the
   storage to create a container + empty archives
2. Avoid us for a COMMIT/ROLLBACK step we would have to handle in the
   metric creation process, in the case where creating a metric either
   storage or indexer would fail – we would have to rollback the
   creation that did not fail.

Cons:

1. We now acknowledge that it's more difficult to have an autonomous
   storage driver working without an indexer. While this was no obvious
   before Gnocchi 1.0.0, it's getting pretty clear now that we don't
   want to bypass the indexer as it's anyway responsible for things such
   as RBAC. And we can anyway cache him.

This will help fixing bug #1483634 since we'll be able to create metric
only in the indexer, doing that in only one single transaction.

This change also handles correctly deletion of unprocessed measures for
metrics that has been deleted.

Change-Id: I81ff5ca5540a8a02d378c289bed611a1329f9325
Related-Bug: #1483634

commit_message:
Remove unused tacker agent code

Remove code related to servicevm configuration & monitoring using
proxy_api and rpc. Tacker no longer uses these mechanisms to
configure and monitor VNFs.

subject: Introduce a resource id translation shim
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-24 19:24:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/ba348c20459beb5e0d0db53f1c74d1b836ce3dc0', 'message': "WIP: Introduce a resource id translation shim

Proof of concept potential solution to the problem described below.
This may be completely insane but since it was easy enough to
implement I thought it worthwhile getting it out for demonstration.

In the openstack environment resource ids are a mismash of UUIDs
(yay!) and other things (boo!). When gnocchi receives a resource id
that is not a UUID, it drops it on the floor with a 400 error.

In some sense this is the exact right thing to do. In others it is
entirely impractical given the use context.

This change introduces a shim which accepts any string as a resource
id, either in the URL or in the Resource voluptuous Schema and does
a transformation on it to turn it into a UUID. That transformation
is:

* check if the string <= 255 in lenght (ValueErrr is not)
* do a sha256 hash of the string
* take the first 32 characters of the hexdigest() to create a UUID
* use the resulting UUID as the local id for the resource

The transform is done for both writes and reads. This is necessary
because we have no control over the caller.

This lack of control is the same reason this change is being
done in gnocchi rather than the ceilometer dispatcher. Gnocchi users
will except to be able to access data in the Gnocchi API by the IDs
they are familiar with. We could consider putting the shim on the
client side but that would demand that everyone use the clients we
make which is a pretty heavy demand.

To make this a complete solution additional testing of more methods
and more URIs would be required. Pushing out for review first.

Concerns with this way of doing things:

* It violates Gnocchi's integrity as an independent thing for the
  sake of OpenStack's problem.
* It makes it hard to dig around in the datastore when there are
  problems (mismatch between natural key and database key).
* Doing a lot of sha256 hashing could get tiring after a while.
* No rigorous evaluation of the potential for collision has yet been
  done.

Pros:

* It keeps UUIDs as the primary identifiers internally.
* If people know about some of the cons they might consider fixing
  their ids.
* It's less intrusive than providing a persistent map between
  OpenStack key and Gnocchi key.
* It requires no indexer-database migration (which a change in id
  structure would).

Probably plenty more pros and cons.

Change-Id: Ibfc58d6f239a0474cbb3ccd9a6229393ada77e8f
Related-Bug: #1480346

that is not a UUID, it drops it on the floor with a 400 error.

In some sense this is the exact right thing to do. In others it is

This change introduces a shim which accepts any string as a resource
id, either in the URL or in the Resource voluptuous Schema and does
a transformation on it to turn it into a UUID. That transformation
is:

* check if the string <= 255 in length (ValueError if not)
* create a uuid5 using RESOURCE_ID_NAMESPACE UUID and the string
* use the resulting UUID as the local id for the resource

This is a recommended form of creating URNs via rfc 4122
https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.txt

The transform is done for both writes and reads. This is necessary
because we have no control over who or what is the the caller using
the API. Gnocchi users will expect to be able to access data in the
Gnocchi API by the IDs they are familiar with.

Doing things this way:

* keeps UUIDs as the primary identifiers internally
* requires no indexer-database migration (which a change in id
  structure would).
* is less intrusive than providing a persistent map between
  OpenStack key and Gnocchi key.
* may raise awareness about the value of using UUIDs everywhere

Change-Id: Ibfc58d6f239a0474cbb3ccd9a6229393ada77e8f
Related-Bug: #1480346
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce a resource id translation shim

In the openstack environment resource ids are a mismash of UUIDs
(yay!) and other things (boo!). When gnocchi receives a resource id
that is not a UUID, it drops it on the floor with a 400 error.

In some sense this is the exact right thing to do. In others it is
entirely impractical given the use context.

This change introduces a shim which accepts any string as a resource
id, either in the URL or in the Resource voluptuous Schema and does
a transformation on it to turn it into a UUID. That transformation
is:

* check if the string <= 255 in length (ValueError if not)
* create a uuid5 using RESOURCE_ID_NAMESPACE UUID and the string
* use the resulting UUID as the local id for the resource

This is a recommended form of creating URNs via rfc 4122
https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.txt

The transform is done for both writes and reads. This is necessary
because we have no control over who or what is the the caller using
the API. Gnocchi users will expect to be able to access data in the
Gnocchi API by the IDs they are familiar with.

Doing things this way:

* keeps UUIDs as the primary identifiers internally
* requires no indexer-database migration (which a change in id
  structure would).
* is less intrusive than providing a persistent map between
  OpenStack key and Gnocchi key.
* may raise awareness about the value of using UUIDs everywhere

Change-Id: Ibfc58d6f239a0474cbb3ccd9a6229393ada77e8f
Related-Bug: #1480346

commit_message:
Remove unecessary parameters to resource methods

Some resource methods are called with parameters they do
not need.  This methods are called with resource ids and/or
path_args and none of them need those parameters.

Change-Id: Ie9f268394d94bb397fe675b2e5ddecc76c33a9e4

Get url for object store object in the normal way

obj.Object was not using _get_url to format the url.  It works
just fine with the _get_url and it is more standard.

Fix resource property id

If a resource property is type=Resource, we should use
id_attribute to determine the key for the id.

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import uuid from openstack.object_store.v1 import container from openstack.object_store.v1 import obj from openstack.tests.functional import base class TestObject(base.BaseFunctionalTest): FOLDER = uuid.uuid4().hex FILE = uuid.uuid4().hex DATA = 'abc' def setUp(self): super(TestObject, self).setUp() self.sot = self.conn.object_store.create_container(name=self.FOLDER) self.sot = self.conn.object_store.create_object( container=self.FOLDER, name=self.FILE, data=self.DATA) def test_list(self): names = [o.name for o in self.conn.object_store.objects(container=self.FOLDER)] self.assertIn(self.FILE, names) def test_get_object(self): # TODO(thowe): Do not require container #1487147 result = self.conn.object_store.get_object( self.sot, container=self.FOLDER) self.assertEqual(self.DATA, result) def test_get_metadata(self): # TODO(thowe): Do not require container #1487147 self.sot.data = None self.sot.set_headers({'x-object-meta-test': 'orly'}) result = self.conn.object_store.set_object_metadata(self.sot) # TODO(thowe): Do not require container #1487147 result = self.conn.object_store.get_object_metadata( self.sot, container=self.FOLDER) self.assertEqual(self.FILE, result.name) headers = result.get_headers() print headers self.assertEqual(str(len(self.DATA)), headers['content-length']) self.assertEqual('orly', headers['x-object-meta-test']) def test_zzzz(self): # TODO(thowe): Do not require container #1487147 self.conn.object_store.delete_object(self.sot, container=self.FOLDER, ignore_missing=False) self.conn.object_store.delete_container(self.FOLDER)

commit_message:
Return complete response from flavors_client part-2

Currently compute flavors_client returns Response by removing
top key from Response.
For example-
return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['flavor_access'])

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current
way of return value. Resource pagination links are present in parallel
(not inside) to top key of Response.

This patch makes flavor-access/extra-specs methods of compute flavors_client
to return complete Response body.

Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib

Change-Id: Id153ba7b5ff838532fd7bf0e2b72815141c2e250

commit_message:
Return complete response from tenant_usages_client

Currently compute tenant_usages_client returns Response by
removing top key from Response.
For example-
 return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['tenant_usage'])

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current
way of return value. Resource pagination links are present in parallel
(not inside) to top key of Response.

This patch makes compute tenant_usages_client to return
complete Response body.

Change-Id: I0e6287b1a720d5f3f129fcaa8c08cf6d40abf8e8
Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib

commit_message:
Return complete response from services_client

Currently compute services_client returns Response by
removing top key from Response.
For example-
 return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['service'])

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current
way of return value. Resource pagination links are present in parallel
(not inside) to top key of Response.

This patch makes compute services_client to return
complete Response body.

Change-Id: I79bc3c14700c3201e8c8ac50e80d5f49c96e52c2
Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib

subject: Make models_v2 explicitly import rbac_db_models
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-24 10:20:42.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/model_base.py', 'neutron/db/models_v2.py', 'neutron/db/rbac_db_models.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2ef027ed39e0398f2dbdd63b09a6a0279d6bc6c4', 'message': 'Make models_v2 explicitly import rbac_db_models

The Network model was implicitly relying on a core plugin to import
the db_base_plugin_v2 module which would import the rbac model module
so "NetworkRBAC" would be defined by the time something would query
the DB. However, this isn't the case for scripts or agents that are
importing models_v2 and trying to query the DB directly so they will
now break with an sqlaclhemy error about a missing model.

This patch makes models_v2 import the rbac_db_models module directly
so the model will always be defined.

This would have resulted in a circular import because the
rbac_db_models module required the HasId and HasTenant classes
in models_v2. So this patch also moves these helper classes
into model_base.

Change-Id: I338ce1c0ba55647e6410a63f937737f75a63057d
Closes-Bug: #1488032
'}]
commit_message:
Make models_v2 explicitly import rbac_db_models

The Network model was implicitly relying on a core plugin to import
the db_base_plugin_v2 module which would import the rbac model module
so "NetworkRBAC" would be defined by the time something would query
the DB. However, this isn't the case for scripts or agents that are
importing models_v2 and trying to query the DB directly so they will
now break with an sqlaclhemy error about a missing model.

This patch makes models_v2 import the rbac_db_models module directly
so the model will always be defined.

This would have resulted in a circular import because the
rbac_db_models module required the HasId and HasTenant classes
in models_v2. So this patch also moves these helper classes
into model_base.

Change-Id: I338ce1c0ba55647e6410a63f937737f75a63057d
Closes-Bug: #1488032
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/77/216177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Return complete response from flavors_client part-1

Currently compute flavors_client returns Response by removing
top key from Response.
For example-
return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['flavor'])

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current
way of return value. Resource pagination links are present in parallel
(not inside) to top key of Response.

This patch makes create/show/list flavor methods of compute flavors_client
to return complete Response body.

Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib

Change-Id: If9ef2db0c78ebfd668c262c2ea57e303c953b048

Sync Gemfile

Update the Gemfile to match the version used in other modules,
and fix lint errors now caught by the updated puppet-lint gem and
puppet-lint plugins.

Change-Id: I64ab4853222a761730762af33f3ddcbec24fce69

add docs job for releases repository

Add the job, non-voting, to build the documentation for the releases
repository. When we have the job working, we'll make it voting.

commit_message:
Do not cache the SQLAlchemy session

The Trove SQLAlchemy handler caches the session. This should not be done
for multi-threaded apps:
http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_1_0/orm/contextual.html

I noticed this when bringing up a cluster. The conductor receives
multiple heartbeats in a short span of time and the shared session
causes an out of sync exception.

The fix is to create a new session whenever it is needed, instead of
accessing a cached version.

Change-Id: I94da76e0a9080f0d2dd287eae0e1d5b23d1ade2e
Closes-bug: #1481493

commit_message:
Add linkcheck for RST

Check RST files for valid links.

This is a separte target for now to evaluate how useful it is.
Whitelist build.opensuse.org URL for user-guide.
Remove also checklang from default tox invocation since it's not needed
to run by default.

Change-Id: I6c275518b9e55ab3b6bcea52894ea851924bee94
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/39/216339/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = checkniceness,checksyntax,checkdeletions,checkbuild,checklinks[testenv:linkcheck] commands = {toxinidir}/tools/build-all-rst.sh --linkcheck

commit_message:
Silence RST building a bit

Remove -x from bash script, we do not need the invocation messages.
Only output sphinx-build invocation for easy reproduction.
Add -b html so that sphinx does not complain about missing builder.

Change-Id: Ic8199a5b7845636ddb72927a4f3c2bd8dc1b58a6

commit_message:
Fix RBAC filters

'index' isn't a valid filter term, and both the glance plugins try to
use it as one, which causes queries to fail for non-admin users. Patch
changes the RBAC filters to use an 'indices' filter which first
restricts on index and then applies the rbac filters and the query.

Change-Id: I35d2703fbb84e1b89e76dee842bb2416a90a999d
Closes-Bug: #1484285

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current

complete Response body.

Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib
"}]
commit_message:
Return complete resp from security_group_rules_client

Currently compute security_group_rules_client returns Response by
removing top key from Response.
For example-
 return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body['security_group_rule'])

As service clients are in direction to move to Tempest-lib, all
service clients should return Response without any truncation.
One good example is Resource pagination links which are lost with current
way of return value. Resource pagination links are present in parallel
(not inside) to top key of Response.

This patch makes compute security_group_rules_client to return
complete Response body.

Change-Id: If0914462b742d4d4c69a9a2e5da8c874acdf5c7f
Implements: blueprint method-return-value-and-move-service-clients-to-lib

Change-Id: Idb6a038a6c0f0ace77b57a68dfc7d678bb2c6e8d
'}]
commit_message:
Spec for virtual IP reservation support in Fuel

Implements: blueprint vip-reservation

Change-Id: Idb6a038a6c0f0ace77b57a68dfc7d678bb2c6e8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/28/194728/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================== Virtual IP reservation ====================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/vip-reservation This document is about additional virtual IP (VIP) reservation during deployment. Problem description =================== Some plugins require additional VIP to proper configuration. For example Zabbix could be configured in way that it expect SNMP traffic on dedicated VIP. In current version VIPs reservation is done based on information from release field in the database. So the plugin developer should have a better way to create extra VIPs as puppet resource in pre-deployment or post-deployment plugin stage. Proposed change =============== Give user a possibility to reserve additional VIPs during deployment process. This should be possible by providing REST API extension to reserve additional VIPs. Deployment flow: None Migration script flow: None Alternatives ------------ VIP requirements for particular network role can be placed in plugin into tasks description. This fits to the current view of flexible networking implementation. Plugin can have its own tasks description already. Network role list should be defined in description of each task and each network role definition there may contain VIP requirements. Network roles to tasks mapping will be parsed by nailgun and VIP requirements will be processed so that VIPs will be assigned before the deployment is started. Cons: - More difficult implementation - API solution gives better ability to manage VIPs Pros: - Better flexibility in some cases Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- We should introduce new API calls which will allow to reserve VIPs in the given network. Upgrade impact -------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- Performance Impact ------------------ None Developer impact ---------------- Developer that works on Fuel plugins can use new API to reserve VIPs for the plugin. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alexander Saprykin (cutwater) Work Items ---------- - Implement new REST API to manage VIPs. - Investigate possibilities to manage VIPs via fuel client. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== We need to update documentation about VIPs in networks. Plugin documentation should be updated as well. References ========== - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/vip-reservation

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-25 04:03:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/982113f701d381a182914c231961d2f2d0455260', 'message': "Allow py34 to run tests individually

Prior to this patch, when I do:

 tox -py34 <my-test>

the argument is ignored and all whitelisted tests are executed.
This is not in line with the other testenv's. This patch ensures
that posargs are processed if available, and that we fall back on
the lot of tests when not specified.

Change-Id: I176d7bba690b1c7e0c64d11528d9c851472b503b
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-25 04:04:16.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/255ef141460e730bc60ab9ad96f830fe16b9422f', 'message': "Allow py34 to run tests individually

Prior to this patch, when I do:

 tox -epy34 <my-test>

the argument is ignored and all whitelisted tests are executed.
This is not in line with the other testenv's. This patch ensures

the lot of tests when not specified.

Change-Id: I176d7bba690b1c7e0c64d11528d9c851472b503b
"}]
commit_message:
Allow py34 to run tests individually

Prior to this patch, when I do:

 tox -epy34 <my-test>

the argument is ignored and all whitelisted tests are executed.
This is not in line with the other testenv's. This patch ensures
that posargs are processed if available, and that we fall back on
the lot of tests when not specified.

Change-Id: I176d7bba690b1c7e0c64d11528d9c851472b503b

commit_message:
Don't try to get aodh endpoint if auth_url didn't provided

This change includes:

* Allow users of ceilometerclient specifying aodh_endpoint explicitly
* If aodh_endpoint didn't provided and users just provide ceilometer
  endpoint and token, no auth_url, we assume aodh is unavailable and
  avoid trying to get aodh endpoint.

Change-Id: Idd0ce60058d23507a99b89926e461d19db267ca2
Closes-Bug: #1488290
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ceilometerclient refs/changes/99/216199/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: aodh_endpoint = kwargs.get('aodh_endpoint') if aodh_endpoint: self.alarm_auth_plugin.opts['endpoint'] = aodh_endpoint elif not kwargs.get('auth_url'): # Users may just provided ceilometer endpoint and token, and no # auth_url, in this case, we need 'aodh_endpoint' also provided, # otherwise we cannot get aodh endpoint from keystone, and assume # aodh is unavailable. else: try: # NOTE(liusheng): Getting the aodh's endpoint to rewrite # the endpoint of alarm auth_plugin. self.alarm_auth_plugin.redirect_to_aodh_endpoint( kwargs.get('timeout')) except exceptions.EndpointNotFound: return self.http_client, False
deleted_lines: try: # NOTE(liusheng): Getting the aodh's endpoint to rewrite # the endpoint of alarm auth_plugin. self.alarm_auth_plugin.redirect_to_aodh_endpoint( kwargs.get('timeout')) except exceptions.EndpointNotFound:

Change the file structure to make appropriate for stand alone parser.

subject: LeftHand driver is ignoring reserved_percentage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-18 23:56:35.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/test_hplefthand.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/san/hp/hp_lefthand_rest_proxy.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/fe77c32fcacb997bb2a08c03e6f17f9b1de92724', 'message': "LeftHand driver is ignoring reserved_percentage

The LH driver was hard coding the reserved_percentage parameter to 0.
The LeftHand driver should be reading this value from the cinder
configuration file as it's used in the capacity filter for calculating
capacities.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib76c191f75300f9607811727b0f08ed09deb06c0
Closes-Bug: 1486267
"}]
commit_message:
LeftHand driver is ignoring reserved_percentage

The LH driver was hard coding the reserved_percentage parameter to 0.
The LeftHand driver should be reading this value from the cinder
configuration file as it's used in the capacity filter for calculating
capacities.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib76c191f75300f9607811727b0f08ed09deb06c0
Closes-Bug: 1486267
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/90/214390/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: data['reserved_percentage'] = ( self.configuration.safe_get('reserved_percentage'))

commit_message:
Adding spec for bp/api-to-oslo-messaging-handler

Spec will describe how api will send messages to the controller.

Partially-Implements: blueprint api-to-oslo-messaging-handler

Change-Id: I429723fd7b8482fe909144d6a8cab3c03716151b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/85/148085/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Title of your blueprint ========================================== Implement API handler to send operations to queue Problem description =================== Proposed change =============== use oslo.messaging to start a listener that will receive create update and delete instructions for api requests. get requests will not need to go through the Queue system. The Queue system should be able to throttle the number of active operations the controller is working on. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None at the moment. But operators should consider configuering their backend Queue system to use SSL. As this is transparent to oslo.messaging it will be up to the operators to configure this. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- The developer of this blueprint should coordinate with the developer working on <insert controller blue print here> implementation to agree on a oslo.messaging contract. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Carlos D. Garza Work Items ---------- For every Class [LoadBalancer, Listener, Pool, HealthMonitor] create a Hanlder class that has a [create, update, delete" method] that instances will use to communicate with the Queue. Create a QueueHandler class that will use use class variables to hold instances of those Handler classes defined above. Then the API can reference those instances via the class attributes. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== References ==========

commit_message:
Configure rpc options separately from ceilometer notifications

Now all rpc backend configurations are setting with ceilometer
notifications. But ceilometer is optional service and rpc
should be configured separately.

Also added new tests for init.pp

Change-Id: I542a8b6ed3aaf18e4b352f821939fc5f262aa5eb

subject: Trap formatting errors
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-17 09:02:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.i18n/commit/2d5483d9187ab037270a37fcadf39f2a20494bba', 'message': "Trap formatting errors

Trap errors when trying to use translated messages as format strings so
translations don't break applications. Log the error, with the format
string (without interpolated values) and the original message so a bug
report can include it to make fixing the translation easier.

Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Change-Id: I5c711b4654b5b2e591bcf365401ff35f7224fe82
Closes-bug: #1339337

Trap errors when trying to use translated messages as format strings so
translations don't break applications. Log the error, with the format
string (without interpolated values) and the original message so a bug
report can include it to make fixing the translation easier.

Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Trap formatting errors

Trap errors when trying to use translated messages as format strings so
translations don't break applications. Log the error, with the format
string (without interpolated values) and the original message so a bug
report can include it to make fixing the translation easier.

Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Change-Id: I5c711b4654b5b2e591bcf365401ff35f7224fe82
Closes-bug: #1339337
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.i18n refs/changes/36/213636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import loggingLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) return self._safe_translate(translated_message, translated_params) def _safe_translate(self, translated_message, translated_params): try: translated_message = translated_message.__mod__(translated_params) except (KeyError, TypeError) as err: # KeyError for parameters named in the translated_message # but not found in translated_params and TypeError for # type strings that do not match the type of the # parameter. # # Log the error translating the message and use the # original message string so the translator's bad message # catalog doesn't break the caller. LOG.debug( (u'Failed to insert replacement values into translated ' u'message %r (Original: %r): %s'), translated_message, self.msgid, err, ) translated_message = self.msgid % translated_params return translated_message unicode_mod = self._safe_translate(super(Message, self), params)
deleted_lines: translated_message = translated_message % translated_params return translated_message unicode_mod = super(Message, self).__mod__(params)

commit_message:
Delete transport test test_debug_post

With the coming of KSA, I think the need for this test will go
away.  KSA actually does a better job of testing this exact
thing.

Partial-Bug: #1487421

Change-Id: Ic474feca00fa110c7f84482010d5c0769da275a6

added_lines: date: 2015-08-25 id: OSSA-2015-015 title: 'Nova instance migration process does not stop when instance is deleted' description: 'George Shuklin from Webzilla LTD reported a vulnerability in Nova migration process. By resizing and deleting an instance repeatedly an authenticated user may overcome his quota and overload Nova computes node resulting in a denial of service attack. All Nova setups are affected.' affected-products: - product: nova version: versions through 2014.2.3 and 2015.1 versions through 2015.1.1 vulnerabilities: - cve-id: CVE-2015-3241 reporters: - name: 'George Shuklin' affiliation: Webzilla LTD reported: - CVE-2015-3241 issues: links: - https://launchpad.net/bugs/1387543 type: launchpad reviews: liberty: - https://review.openstack.org/194861 - https://review.openstack.org/192986 kilo: - https://review.openstack.org/213234 - https://review.openstack.org/209856 juno: - https://review.openstack.org/208876 - https://review.openstack.org/214528 type: gerrit notes: - 'This fix requires oslo.concurrency >= 1.8.2 for Kilo and >= 2.3.0 for Liberty. Juno fix embeds a patched version of oslo.concurrency' - 'This fix will be included in future 2014.2.4 (juno) and 2015.1.2 (kilo) releases.'

commit_message:
Enable HAProxy Stats Web UI

This patch enables the HAProxy webstats for all the configures
backends and frontends.

A password entry is added to user_secrets.yml for the webstats
password.

It also adds variables for port number, username and password
which can be overridden in user_variables.yml appropriately.

Change-Id: Iec866ad124bec6fb0b8524a966adf64e22422035
Closes-Bug: #1446432
